ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned spanish
Improved my Spanish skills and cultural competency
Speaking the most

You develop new grammar skills that build on those taught in SPAN120, and get to look at the work of Hispanic writers, filmmakers, and artists. This class gives you a good view of Hispanic culture and focuses on developing comprehension and speaking skills.

My pronunciation and general communication skills in Spanish drastically improved, along with significantly greater writing skills including grammar and vocabulary and analysis skills of literature and films in Spanish.

This was a great course, and I learned so so much! My speaking, writing, and reading in Spanish improved a lot this semester, and this was a much more engaging class than high school Spanish. I learned a lot about Spanish and Latin American cultures, as well as about the phrases that are commonly used and proper grammar.
Useful communicative skills that I will use throughout my life

From this course, I developed Spanish language skills, specifically writing and speaking as well as more advanced grammar and vocabulary. This Spanish class was very focused on longer writing pieces and analysis of films/stories in Spanish.
Spanish

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Loved the project based structure, did not love some of the organization

Strengths - Prof. Diaz is very helpful and the course itself is rather interesting.

Weaknesses - It is often difficult to know what to do before class each day. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have questions, but the organization of the course could certainly be improved.
Its fun but it could be improved with better organization.

Having the course four days per week is a strength as I felt my understanding and knowledge of the language improved from very frequent practice. Seminar-style is also a strength of the course. The course might be improved from clearer organization on Canvas of assignments, files, videos, readings, and tasks for the week.

I really enjoyed this course. The content was very engaging, and I think I learned a lot. I would prefer to have an in-person class instead of asynchoronous Wednesday. The only weakness is that the pace is sometimes very quick and a lot of content is covered, but that is also a strength of this course.
Better ability to see/understand how you are doing through the semester. Less overly complicated spanish stories

This course incorporated a lot of fascinating readings and films into the syllabus, which made the class discussions very enjoyable. Also, the workload for this course was very manageable. However, it was often unclear what work was due, when it was due, and the exact instructions. This course needed a syllabus that was better organized and a standardized system of turning in and receiving back work. Additionally, I wish assignments had been posted earlier. We have Supersite practice daily at the beginning of the semester, and it wouldn't be posted until the afternoon and was due at 9 the following day. This made it easy to forget about, and I often checked early in the day, saw nothing, but then had to go back and do the assignments late at night.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only for language requirment
Honestly, yes. This is the only Spanish course at Yale that I have really enjoyed.
Yes, if you are interested in becoming more proficient in Spanish and learning about Hispanic culture. You apply new grammar skills and gain conversational Spanish abilities.

Yes. Spanish L3 is extremely challenging in workload, frequency, and the quality of work demanded by the course. However, its high demand in time and energy yields results, and my Spanish skillsin comprehension, reading, writing, speaking, and analysishave markedly improved.

Yes! This was such a fun class and I loved taking it! I definitely recommend professor Diaz! He is such an incredible and engaging lecturer! This class can feel like a lot of work at times, but you truly learn so much valuable content and it is fun!
yes but often required
This course was a good class to get through language requirements with. It wasn't particularly fascinating, but it improved my Spanish skills without too much additional stress.
